title: Percy S. Prince
text:
Percy S. Prince (April 7, 1882 – December 12, 1930) was an <a href="American%20football">American football</a>, <a href="basketball">basketball</a>, and <a href="baseball">baseball</a> coach at the Louisiana Industrial Institute—now known as <a href="Louisiana%20Tech%20University">Louisiana Tech University</a>—and St. Stephen's College—now known as <a href="Bard%20College">Bard College</a>.
Prince graduated from <a href="Tufts%20University">Tufts University</a> in 1906 and served as an assistant football coach at Tufts in 1907. He became the head football coach at Louisiana Industrial in 1909 and coached the football team through the <a href="1915%20Louisiana%20Industrial%20football%20team">1915 season</a> in which Louisiana Industrial won the <a href="Louisiana%20Intercollegiate%20Athletic%20Association">Louisiana Intercollegiate Athletic Association</a> (LIAA) championship, the program's first conference title. Prince also coached the Louisiana Industrial baseball team in 1910, tallying a mark of 14–4.
With the United States engaged in <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, Prince left coaching to serve as a <a href="Captain%20%28United%20States%29">captain</a> in the 1st Regiment of Infantry with headquarters at <a href="Monroe%2C%20Louisiana">Monroe</a> under Colonel Frank P. Stubbs Jr. Prince served as the Supply Company Commander. After his regiment landed in <a href="Brest%2C%20France">Brest, France</a>, on September 3, 1918, Prince's regiment became part of the <a href="39th%20Infantry%20Division%20%28United%20States%29">39th Infantry Regiment</a> and was eventually reorganized as the <a href="156th%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">156th Infantry Regiment</a>. They were finally assigned to a training camp near <a href="Saint-Florent-sur-Cher">Saint Florent</a>. Prince was promoted from captain to <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a>.
After the conclusion of the war, Prince returned to <a href="Ruston%2C%20Louisiana">Ruston</a> to coach the Louisiana Industrial football team for the 1919 season. HIs career football record at Louisiana Industria was 24–16–5.
In 1920, Prince moved to <a href="Annandale-on-Hudson%2C%20New%20York">Annandale-on-Hudson, New York</a>, to coach basketball and base at St. Stephen's College, which has since changed its name to <a href="Bard%20College">Bard College</a>. He left St. Stephen's in 1923.
Prince was born in <a href="Salem%2C%20Massachusetts">Salem, Massachusetts</a>. He died on December 12, 1930, at <a href="Delaware%20Hospital">Delaware Hospital</a> in <a href="Wilmington%2C%20Delaware">Wilmington, Delaware</a>.
